title: ‘Jem and the Holograms’ a weirdly entertaining mix
text:
Photo: Universal Pictures Image 1 of / 1 1 Stefanie Scott, Aubrey Peeples, Hayley Kiyoko and Aurora Perrineau in "Jem and the Holograms." (Justina Mintz/Universal Pictures) Stefanie Scott, Aubrey Peeples, Hayley Kiyoko and Aurora Perrineau in "Jem and the Holograms." (Justina Mintz/Universal Pictures) Photo: Universal Pictures ‘Jem and the Holograms’ a weirdly entertaining mix 1 / 1 Back to Gallery There’s a cute robot sidekick in “Jem and the Holograms.” It looks like an iMac G4 and Curious George had a baby, it dances and produces light shows, and it’s maybe the fourth most weirdly distracting thing about this big-screen reboot of the 1980s animated cartoon.
“Jem” is one of those pieces of cinema that manages to entertain completely in spite of itself. It’s fun and family-friendly; trying earnestly to understand young people, without making any chaperones in the audience feel left out. It’s also predictable, presenting a theme about artistic independence that is a complete contradiction. And then there’s that robot — looking like it escaped from the last “Transformers” film.
More Information Jem and the Holograms
★★
Quick take: A decnet film with a condradictory message
That’s actually a viable theory. Both movies are based on Hasbro creations, trying to simultaneously capitalize on Generation X’s love of nostalgia and the short attention spans of whatever this generation of ‘tweens is going to be called. The goal here is a bazillion dollars in merchandise, and a hastily made sequel with a stylized title (“Jem and the Hologram2”?) that looks good on a movie poster.
“Nashville” star Aubrey Peeples is a solid choice as Jem, the least outgoing but most talented of four sisters who have music in their blood. A flurry of mistakes, coincidences and double-crosses turn her into an internet sensation. Lured by mega-producer Erica Raymond ( Juliette Lewis , channeling equal parts Anna Wintour and Cruella de Vil), Jem must decide whether to become a solo act, save her aunt’s home and solve a mystery that is linked to her artistic future.
In addition to the robot, here are the other three most weirdly distracting things in “Jem,” in no particular order.
All of the girls appear to be between 14 and 20 years old, and their schooling isn’t mentioned once during the entire film.
Jem’s dead father sends her on a byzantine scavenger hunt, involving several misdemeanors and at least one felony, so she can receive information he could have just written on an index card and handed to a notary.
Lewis and Ryan Guzman play mother and son, despite appearing to be maybe nine years apart in age.
The scenes with Lewis are some of the most entertaining, but they also sink the film’s central moral that it’s OK to be yourself and buck the corporate bad guys. Jem’s fight against an evil profit-centric record company comes in a movie made by a profit-centric movie studio, co-produced by a toy company CEO and the guy who represents Justin Bieber . It’s like watching a film that decries the exploitation of whales, financed by Sea World with Captain Ahab attached as an executive producer.
To be fair, there are positives that come from these alliances as well. Much like the completely satisfactory Bieber concert film “Never Say Never,” the “Jem” movie has a nice understanding of fame, fandom and the power of social media. “Jem and the Holograms” weaves in its 21st century vibe without feeling forced or self-conscious.
And to balance the modern touches, there are 1980s references galore, beginning and ending with the greatest 1980s totem of them all: Molly Ringwald starring as Jem’s aunt. This is the most full-circle part of the film - with Ringwald basically playing the Paul Dooley kind father role from “Sixteen Candles.”
The movie ends (minor spoiler here) with a speech (“We’re all Jem!”) extremely similar to the one Sylvester Stallone made at the end of “Rocky IV.” That movie also had a robot, a lot of montages and made less sense the more you thought about it. Everything eventually comes back in style …
Running time: 108 minutes
MPAA rating: PG (reckless behavior, suggestive content, profanity)
